intro: Cinchona tovarensis, commonly known as the Tovarensis quinine tree, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and distinctive red flowers. The plant is notable for its bark, which contains alkaloids such as quinine, historically used in the treatment of malaria. It typically grows in humid, shaded environments at moderate elevations. Due to its medicinal significance and habitat specificity, it is considered a valuable yet endangered species in its native range.
